canada_case_details.detail: A man in his 50s who arrived in Toronto from Wuhan, China, the epicentre of the outbreak.  The man called 911 as soon as he got sick with relatively minor symptoms and was placed in isolation in Toronto’s Sunnybrook Hospital.
canada_case_details.recovered: Recovered but are still testing positive for coronavirus

canada_case_details.detail: Wife of the Toronto man who was Canada’s first case of the new coronavirus. The woman had recently travelled to Wuhan, China, with her husband. The woman is kept in home isolation.
canada_case_details.recovered: Recovered but are still testing positive for coronavirus

canada_case_details.detail: A male in his forties and a resident in Vancouver. He travels regularly to China for work and was in Wuhan city on his most recent trip. He returned to Vancouver last week and had an onset of symptoms after his return.
canada_case_details.recovered: Resolved with two successive negative test results 24 hours apart.

canada_case_details.detail: A woman in her 20s, an University student from London, Ontario, had travelled to the affected area in China.
canada_case_details.recovered: Resolved with two separate negative tests

canada_case_details.detail: A woman in her 50s who resides in the Vancouver Coastal Health region. The individual had close contact with family visitors from Wuhan city and is in isolation at home.
One individual is male, the other female, and both are in their 30s. They are visitors to the Vancouver Coastal Health region from Hubei province, China.
A female in her 30s. She lives in the Interior Health region and recently flew into YVR from Shanghai, China.
A woman in her 30s, who resides in the Fraser Health region and who recently returned from Iran.

A woman arrived in Canada from China on Friday and went to North York General Hospital in Toronto with an intermittent cough. The woman was tested for the new virus, known as COVID-19, and was sent home for self isolation because her illness was mild.

The person affected is male, in his 40s and lives in the Fraser Health region. He was in close contact with the previously reported sixth case announced on Feb. 20, 2020. Both cases remain in isolation at home with support and monitoring from public health teams.

Sunnybrook hospital received confirmation of a positive test result for COVID-19 from a patient who presented at our Emergency Department on Monday evening, February 24.  Proper isolation precautions were followed and there is no risk to others who were in the ED at that time. The patient presented with symptoms and a recent travel history to Iran.  Fortunately, the patient's condition did not require admission to hospital and the person was discharged home to follow self-isolation protocols.

The husband of a woman confirmed as Ontario's fifth case of COVID-19 has also tested positive for coronavirus. The man in his 60s is at home in Toronto in self-isolation. His only symptoms are a mild cough and fever.

The first probable case of COVID-19 has been detected in a patient who recently returned from a trip to Iran. The patient, a woman, went to a clinic in the Montreal region on Monday with minor symptoms.  Measures were quickly put in place to protect the health network and the community,  The woman did not take public transit to get to the clinic, and she hadn't gone back to work since returning from Iran.

A man in his 50s presented himself at Sunnybrook Health Sciences Centre's emergency department with a recent travel history to Iran. The patient was cared for at the hospital using all appropriate precautions, including being isolated as he was being tested for COVID-19. The man had arrived from Iran the day before. The man was discharged the same day and was told to go into self-isolation at home.

A man in his 80s presented himself at Scarborough Health Network's General Hospital's emergency department on February 27, 2020, with a travel history to Egypt. The patient was cared for at the hospital using all appropriate precautions, including being isolated as he was tested for COVID-19. The man was discharged home the same day feeling well and went into self-isolation where he remains. Throughout his travels, the man wore a mask.

The person affected is visiting from Tehran, Iran and arrived in British Columbia earlier this week. The individual is female, in her 60s and is staying with family in the Vancouver Coastal Health region. The patient is in isolation at home with support and monitoring from public health teams.

A woman, 34, who had just returned from Iran, went to Mackenzie Health, a Richmond Hill, Ont., hospital, on Thursday.  York Region public health officials have begun a search for anyone who might have come in contact with the case, either in the air or on a GO bus to Richmond Hill.

A woman, 51, and her husband, 69. The women had just returned from Iran. A 51-year-old woman returned from Iran on Feb. 22 and went to an Ajax clinic on Friday with a cough, body aches and chills. She was masked and isolated. She was tested for the virus at Lakeridge Health Ajax Pickering hospital. Her 69-year-old husband, meanwhile, also tested positive for the virus on Friday. He had a cough, but did not go to Iran.  He accompanied his wife to the Ajax clinic and Lakeridge Health Ajax Pickering hospital. He was also tested for the virus. Both were discharged from the hospital, sent home and went into self-isolation.

Three of the latest cases are in York Region. One of the patients, a man in his 40s, is the husband of the region's first patient announced on Saturday, a 34-year-old woman. The man travelled with his wife to Iran and back to Canada. Second case in York Region is a woman in her 70s, from Newmarket, who is a contact of the positive case in Toronto who is believed to have contracted the virus in Egypt. The third case is a man in his 60s, who returned from Iran on Sunday, Feb. 23 , presented himself to North York General Hospital's emergency department on Friday. The man informed the hospital of a cough and recent travel history. He was assessed and discharged home on the same day.

A man in his 50s, a Toronto resident who is temporarily residing in the city of Vaughan. He is the brother of one of Toronto's recently reported cases who had also travelled to Iran, arriving at Pearson on Feb. 25. The man had been assessed and tested at Mackenzie Health, a Richmond Hill, Ont., hospital, on Friday, Feb. 28. He is in self-isolation.
The latest three cases included two women in their 60s and 70s who returned from Egypt on Feb. 20, and a man in his 60s who returned from Iran on Feb. 23.
One person was travelling from Iran and the other from Egypt. These new cases are in the GTA and they are at home in self-isolation.
The patient is a man in his 50s who had recently returned from a trip to Iran. The man, who lives in the Fraser Health region, and his close contacts are all in isolation.

All three new cases reside in the Vancouver Coastal Health region and have recently returned from travel to Iran. Case 10 is a man and in his 60s and case 11 is a woman. They have no connection to previous confirmed cases. Case 12 is a woman in her 30s and a close contact of the eighth case, previously reported on Feb. 29.

Health officials have identified eight new COVID-19 infections in British Columbia. Half of them are 'close household contacts' to one previously identified COVID-19 patient who recently returned from a trip to Iran. But one of the newly identified patients is a woman who hasn't travelled to any COVID-19 affected countries and has no known contact with anyone in B.C. carrying the virus. Two of the other newly identified patients live in the same household and recently returned from travel to Iran, while the last is a Seattle resident who is visiting family in B.C.'s Fraser Health region.

A Mississauga man in his 60s was seen and assessed at Trillium Health Partners – Mississauga Hospital.  The man was aboard the Grand Princess Cruise Ship out of San Francisco from Feb. 11 to 21 and returned to Canada on Feb. 28. The man is recovering in self-isolation at home.

A woman in her 50s who returned from Italy on Tuesday presented herself in Kitchener, Ont., where she was assessed, tested and sent home the same day.  The patient has mild symptoms and is in self-isolation at home in minimal contact with others. The woman had mild symptoms on her Air Portugal flight from Milan to Lisbon, Flight 827, and on her Air Portugal flight from Lisbon to Toronto, Flight 259, on March 3. The woman has a small family, and its members are also in self-isolation.

A man in his 60s who returned from Iran on Saturday went to Sunnybrook Health Sciences Centre's emergency department in Toronto on Tuesday. He was assessed and sent home on the same day. He's currently in self-isolation.

The latest Toronto case revealed Thursday night is a person who travelled to Las Vegas for an international conference. The person went to the Emergency Department at Toronto Western Hospital Wednesday with respiratory symptoms.

A woman in her 50s whom they believe contracted COVID-19 while aboard the Grand Princess cruise ship out of California. She returned home to the Calgary Zone on Feb. 21 and has been self-isolating since Feb. 28.
The patient, a male, is a resident of the Laurentian community of Mont-Laurier who had travelled to India tested positive for COVID-19. The man is in stable condition and is in quarantine.
